Award.AwardTitle: REVSYS: Relationships, Diversification, and Monographic study of the Poorly-known Loeselia Clade (Polemoniaceae)
Award.AbstractNarration:
Loeselia is an obscure and little studied lineage in the flowering plant family Polemoniaceae (phlox family), which includes two genera: Loeselia L. and Dayia J.M. Porter. Despite the lack of detailed knowledge about the lineage, Loeselia has played a pivotal role in hypotheses concerning the origin of temperate members of Polemoniaceae from tropical ancestors. This research program will provide a better understanding of Loeselia (with 22 or more species). Preliminary studies of comparative DNA sequences provide evidence that Loeselia is composed of two groups of species based on ancestry, corresponding to Loeselia L. and Dayia J.M. Porter. Exhaustive taxon sampling within Loeselia and dense sampling of related groups will be used to develop an understanding of genealogical relationships (phylogeny) within and among species, using chloroplast and nuclear DNA sequences, morphological, and anatomical data.

Evidence generated through this research will lead to a new classification system and the first comprehensive monographs of Loeselia, including keys, descriptions, illustrations, distribution maps, and on-line resources. The studies of character evolution, using the same data, will provide a model for analyses of variation in reproductive traits such as self-incompatibility and floral symmetry, which is thought to be an important generator of flowering plant diversity.

POR.DRECONTENT:
REVSYS: Relationships, Diversification, and Monographic study of the Poorly-known Loeselia Clade (Polemoniaceae) is a grant that explores the species diversity of Loeselia and Dayia, two closely-related groups within the flowering plant family often referred to as the Phlox family. These genera occur in the southwestern United States and extend into Mexico, Central America and into parts of South America. The overall goals were to use a combination of field, museum, and laboratory studies to develop an understanding of the diversity and genealogical relationships among the species, leading to the development of a comprehensive monograph, describing this lineage. To do this, we have increase the specimen resources for the Loeselia clade, including making collections of herbarium specimens, DNA and other biological materials to support this comparative study. We have employed high- throughput DNA sequencing to produce the first whole chloroplast genomes in the family, as well as sample 55 nuclear genes. This wealth of data has provided unparalleled inference into the relationships, age and evolution of Loeselia and Dayia. Although these genera are of equal age, the former is expanding in range in recent times, diversifying in pollination system, while the later displays a much lower speciation rate, with a significant portion on the brink of extinction. We can show that the ecology of species (or in some cases populations within species) influences the breeding systems (whether a species self-pollinates or outcrosses). The more extreme the aridity, the more likely the species is to be self-pollinating and to have reduced flower size.

 This research has contributed to the education and research experience of advanced learning by its support for the training of five graduate students, in the form of research assistantships. It has further supported the training of 49 undergraduate students (10 of which were granted stipends), through Rancho Santa Ana Botanic Garden’s Systematics Research Institute (SRI) for Undergraduates, an intensive research experience in modern systematic botany. This grant has supported the development of a workshop and graduate-level course describing modern high-throughput DNA sequencing and analysis, which are becoming essential approaches in this field of study. Portions of this research have been presented to the general public through presentations at public gardens and in particular, Rancho Santa Ana Botanic Garden.
